title: China and Taiwan go to war over Wikipedia edits as hundreds of changes are uncovered
text:
Hundreds of recently uncovered Chinese edits to Taiwan's Wikipedia page have revealed the country's attempts to claim ownership of the state.

Within the space of a single day, the description of Taiwan will change from 'a state in East Asia' to 'a province in the People's Republic of China', umpteen times.

And the mysterious Wikipedia edits haven't only affected Taiwan.

The page for the Hong Kong protests was changed 65 times in one day. Page writers kept disagreeing whether the people were protesters or rioters.

Hundreds of recently uncovered Chinese edits to Taiwan's Wikipedia page have revealed the country's attempts to claim ownership of the state

And while the English entry about the Senkaku islands claimed they were 'islands in East Asia', the Mandarin equivalent was edited to include 'China's inherent territory'.

The 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, which Amnesty International estimates had a death toll of 1,000, were changed in Mandarin to 'the June 4th incident' to 'quell the counter-revolutionary riots'.

The pro-democracy protests began on April 15, 1989, but were forcibly stopped when the government declared martial law and sent the military in, in an event sometimes referred to as the Tiananmen Square Massacre.

The massacre saw the military occupy central parts of Beijing and troops with assault rifles and tanks fired at demonstrators.

The Wikipedia page for the Hong Kong protests was changed 65 times in one day. Page writers kept disagreeing whether the people were protesters or rioters

Estimates of the death toll vary from several hundreds to several thousands.

The Dalai Lama is described as a Tibetan refugee on the Wikipedia's English entry page whereas in Mandarin, he is a Chinese exile.

Jamie Lin, a board member of Wikimedia Taiwan, believes what was once an incredible font of knowledge for the masses, is under attack.

She told the BBC: 'It's control by the Chinese Government. That's very terrible.'

A BBC Click investigation found almost 1,600 biased edits across 22 politically sensitive articles but it wasn't able to find who made each of them.

Some academics argue that because of foreign media, Wikipedia entries have a large number of prejudiced words against the Chinese government.

Academics Li-hao Gan and Bin-Ting Weng said: 'China urgently needs to encourage and train Chinese netizens to become Wikipedia platform opinion leaders and administrators… who can adhere to socialist values and form some core editorial teams.'

And a new concept of 'telling China's story' has gained traction over the past couple of years.

Some Taiwanese Wikipedians have reported receiving death threats on the Wikimedia Telegram Channel.

The Dalai Lama is described as a Tibetan refugee on the Wikipedia's English entry page whereas in Mandarin, he is a Chinese exile

One read: 'The policemen will enjoy your mother's forensic report.'

China is known for systematically manipulating online social media on Twitter and Facebook.

So Heather Ford, a senior lecturer in digital cultures at the University of New South Wales, whose research has focused on the political editing of Wikipedia wasn't surprised that the country is now targeting Wikipedia.

She said: 'I'm surprised it's taken this long actually… It is a prioritised source of facts and knowledge about the world.'
description: The description of Taiwan changes from a 'state in East Asia' to a 'province in the People's Republic of China'. And the Hong Kong protests page was changed at least 65 times in a single day.
